author: potuz
content: <@425572898787426305> <@543900561460822016> this is what I mentioned to you Misha the other day, it looks reasonable to me, it would decouple completely syncing and we could do this now that we are separating some fields out of the payload (like requests). On ePBS all the required fields are already outside of the payload and into a payload envelope https://hackmd.io/@potuz/HkZ5ZWv6A

author: jwasinger
content:
I have added the benchmark vectors [here](https://github.com/holiman/goevmlab/tree/245b0c863ea3f2bec95788ce6db8a7829355ffb4/examples/bls12381bench/benchmarks)

the naming format is `{"bench"/"noop"}-{target precompile}-{input count}.json` where `bench` means that the test consists of a number of calls to the target benchmark (2850 if the input count is <= 32, 100 if it is above).  `noop` tests consist of calls to the identity precompile (without any calldata input); same number of calls as the corresponding `bench` tests. `input count` is only relevant for pairing and msm precompiles, and indicates number of pairs in the precompile input.

Inputs are of the same form as described [here](https://github.com/jwasinger/eip2537-evm-benchmarks?tab=readme-ov-file#benchmark-inputs), generated by a go executable in the parent dir [here](https://github.com/holiman/goevmlab/blob/245b0c863ea3f2bec95788ce6db8a7829355ffb4/examples/bls12381bench/main.go#L313-L411)

author: jwasinger
content: for geth and msm specifically, I found that the results from the state-test-packaged benchmarks were off significantly.  Whereas the previous benchmarks in https://github.com/jwasinger/eip2537-evm-benchmarks ,  that only specify benchmark EVM code and input data, were closer to geth's native bls benchmark performance.
